number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												I have been a fan of the Age of Wonders series since the very beginning. The series has been my favorite when it comes to strategy games. I was extremely excited when Triumph Studios announced the third installment of the series. I have watched the status of AOW III develop from the initial announcement up until release.So, here is my review based on 10 ours of in-game experience. I am extremely impressed with the AI. It is a much greater improvement over the original games. The AI is really taking me for run! I never had much challenge with the AI in the previous games. I like the detailed terrain and atmosphere of the maps/world. The tactical combats are sweet and prettier than the previous games. Also, the tactical AI is much smarter as well. In AOW II SM, I would lure enemies out of the gate in a siege and slaughter them... it doesn't work like that anymore. :D The AI is tough and smarter. The soundtrack is AWESOME! I wish I would have got the deluxe edition just for the soundtrack. I'll have to wait until they release it as DLC. I love how the knights look in AOW III. Their armor shines as they sit on their steeds with their lances; it brings a nice heroic personality. During the 10 hours of in-game experiences I have really enjoyed game. It is fun, exciting, and challenging. I rate it a 9/10 in my opinion.Here are some of the things I would suggest to improve AOW III. Angels... I really miss the angels from AOW II. Beautiful females, powerful, and celestial beings. They were my favorite unit, and I love how they could only be summoned. AOW III has angelic-like beings called the exalted. However, they just don't fit in the game as the female angels would. Another thing reflecting back upon the angels is that you can also get goblin angels, human angels, dwarf angels, etc... This is due to the new class system in AOW III. Angels, succubus, etc need to be unique, and preferably summoned instead of being standard recruitable creatures. I am hoping Triumph will bring back the angels from AOW II as summons. :) Another thing I would suggest is to bring back the old method of handling flying creatures. In AOW II you needed magic, another flying unit, ranged units, or for the flying unit to attack you in order to deal damage to a flying unit. Based on what I have seen all creatures whether flying or not can hit a flying unit. Lastly, I do prefer the 2d art for heroes and leaders as compared to the 3d stuff (lowest priority).In conclusion, Age of Wonders III is a solid game that will bring an exciting and challenging experience. I am very happy with my purchase and will continue to support Triumph Studio on further development of Age of Wonders III! 9/10!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												Age of Wonders III has really managed to hit my itch for a great game. There are seemingly infinite customization combinations  for creating a random map. I have counted 36 race/class(6x6) combos and then there are the specializations, all of which can have a pretty big impact on how your character's empire will be played. Editing the physical appearance of your character is kind of limited in my opinion but that did not ruin anything for me, i had already spent a half an hour debating what I would play first. Adding to the changing of physical appearance items crafted and found while playing will show on your character (only in battle i think). The AI has proven to be a challenge for me, to keep it simple they don't seem to play fair or nice things have gone poorly for me several times. The fourth difficulty which I believe is called 'king' is too much for me currently. I do a lot of empire building, and i have played with the scenarios however i haven't played though either of the two stories yet. When building my empire in a random map I find myself ready to sit there for hours leading my character and other heroes on a quests to help and save cities and then conquer those who don't want peace. I have logged in around 40 hours so far, much of which was spent using local multiplayer. All of my friends around here play consoles but a few do enjoy games like this one so it was great being able to have them over and play this. Turns can get pretty long late game (using classic turn based system opposed to simultaneous) on the bigger maps but when all you have to do is past a wireless mouse back and forth its easy to do other things while waiting. Even so between turns waiting on the AI doesn't take nearly as long many other games similar to this style I've played.I'm actually bored of writing this now and really want to go play more Age of Wonders III before i start my day, so take care everyone and if you haven't checked out this game I seriously suggest you do. Really you guys/girls/lords/ladies...do it right the frack now! Go play as a goblin dreadnought and blow some things up you'll have loads of fun! and nothing beats fun...

content:
8, 2016
												This is the best hex-style turn based strategy game I have played. The game offers very distinct empire classes to play, each with a very unique playstyle and unit set. You can also select a race which augments your class by giving your base units special traits and skills. Every class is surprisingly balanced with the exception of Dreadnought, which is significanty overpowered.What I love most about this game is its combat system which is very deep but at the same time completely transparent. All units possess unique traits and interactions which if leveraged perfectly, can turn a likely defeat into a flawless victory. Units can level up and earn promotions that give them not just plain stats, but additional skills and traits making them more suited to their combat role. The addition of a wide array of global combat spells also adds depth to the game.This game is a must buy if you enjoy games like Civ, or if you want a game similar to the HoMM series but with balanced gameplay and game depth.

content:
28, 2015
												I have 342 hours into the game as of this review, and have only played single player.  This is easily the most played game in my Steam library. (Skyrim comes in at 2nd, with about 275 hours as of this review.  And whatever is in 3rd place is so far back, it can't even see the dust from these two.)  I find this funny, since I almost passed on buying AoW3.This is a deep game, which took me about 60 hours just to feel like I was getting the feel of all the possibilities.  The intro campaign got a bit tedious by about the 4th chapter, so I jumped into random maps.  Very enjoyable!  Just about anything you can think of is customizable, including your leader's race, specialty, and appearance; to map type, size and features (the map can be dangerous and rewarding... at the same time); to number of heros allowed and their max levels...  Oh yes, and the number, skill and specialties of your A.I. opponents are individually tweakable.  Basically, after you haved played a bit, each random map is a game you can fully and intelligently customize to optimize the challenge and maximize your own enjoyment.The strategy level is turn-based or semi-real time (selectable) and the combat is turn-based.  Decisions you make at the strategy/map level greatly influence numbers and capabilities of troops you field.  The tactical combat is deep.  With the right skills and knowledge, you can defeat far superior opponents (or vice versa: you can get your fanny kicked by an inferior opponent).  Your opponents are scalable in toughness, and total defeat is definitely an option.  Making the right decisions at both the strategic and tactical levels makes for very satisfying play.A lot of attention was given to the audio and visual experience.  The map and game pieces are beautiful.  Every troop has its own unque sounds and animations for different actions, including combat.  There is a bit of an RPG element --> Heros and leaders get stronger if you cultivate them, have many different capabilities, based on class, and really can make a big difference in battle outcomes.Due to the fact that I think the tutorial campaign could have been a little more "teachy" AND interesting, I lower my ranking a bit below perfect, and give this game a rating of 9 out of 10.

												I strongly recommend this game. The variety of strategies and choices is outstanding. Every hero, race and unit feels very unique. Every expansion improved the base game really fine.Age of Wonders III feels really  different from other turn strategy when we look at battle mechanics. I can't say how good it feels in my hands. In a battle with 32+ units, one badly unit move can turn the tides.And after almost two campaign I still have not experienced a single major bug.However, after two year of paths and ballancing, it still has some flaws, for example:- Tier IV units making tier I units almosts useless in late game- Limited controls. There's too many repetitive mouse actions that can't mapped to a hotkey.- Some of campaign levels are way too long. Managing 10+ cities is not funny while hunting enemies heroes around other 10+ cities.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This game is addictive as hell. Whether youre a fan of the old series, as i am, or a newcomer who enjoys 4X games, Age of Wonders III will keep you persistently hungry for "one more turn". I have not played the campaign much (i never do in these games) but the skirmish/random map mode is exactly what i want out of games like this.Exploration is very rewarding in AOW3, as each randomly generated world feels rich and large. Whatever method, pattern, or logic it is that the world generator uses, it does its job; mountains, forests, and rivers all fit very naturally together, have plenty of variety with sensibly placed climates/regions, and just look wonderful. The resources are spaced and balanced really well, and there are tons of dungeons and rare encounters to discover and conquer. I always get absorbed in roaming the world, every time.Hero creation is fun. The classes are mostly what you are used to (warriors, wizards, priests, etc), but there are many combinations of race/class/specializations available whos impacts on the game are felt gradually over the course of your campaign, and every change can have a major impact on how you play, so it is easy to get excited about trying out each one. Personally, i spend almost as much time creating heroes and imagining up personalities for them as i do actually playing the game (LOL), and the fact that i can make them, not only for myself, but for the NPCs as well really gets me into the game alot more than i would be otherwise.There are plenty of spells, including hidden ones, plenty of items and equipment, including some you make yourself, and plenty of monsters, most of which you can learn to either capture or acquire for your own armies. Some units have unique abilities when certain classes and races combine to produce them, and each hero can be customized with RPG-style level-upgrades and equipment. There are also rare units which can only be discovered through exploration, or by conquering/befreinding key locations, so even play throughs with the same customized faction will vary and feel different.The tactical combat is better than i have seen in a 4X game in a long time. Many different unit roles exist, with a variety of strengths and positions which counter them, and each has advantages at different times. Combined with heroes and spells, there are many things to think about in battle, and many strategies to win with. The sheer number of unit abilities in this game is impressive in its own right, but once you begin to realize that every single one of them counters, and is countered by, something else, things move to a whole new level. The action-point and flanking systems ensure that you cannot simply hire a few beefy units and chop your way through hordes of enemies... there is a limit to how much one badass can do in a turn, and you WILL be outmaneuvered and killed by cheap little weaklings if you do not position your units correctly.If i had to complain about something in this game, i could only think of two things to mention. Firstly, the diplomacy mechanics are ♥♥♥♥. To be fair, they usually are in 4X games; diplomacy rarely ever gets implimented well into games which are mostly designed around combat but, in this case, it feels especially worthless. Most NPCs will decide whether or not they are at war with you before you even open the diplomacy screen, and once it has been decided there is really nothing you can do to change things. There isnt much you can trade, and NPCs will typically never accept a trade anyway, so this much of the game may as well be removed.And Secondly, the difficulty of the game is spasmatic at best. One game, you may walk over everyone else as though they werent even there, and the next you may be clinging to life every turn; there seems to be no consistency even within the same difficulty levels of this game. I have had several matches where i have spent hours exploring the world only to find one of the enemy factions tucked away in a corner of the map repeatedly failing to extablish a second city for some reason or another, and i have also had matches where all of my cities were under constant siege by max level units before i had even located an enemy. It is wildly inconsistent and, if you do not limit the number of heroes a faction may have, AI factions will hire as many as they can afford to the exclusion of everything else.But, the game is amazing and has only been getting better with each patch. As far as i am concerned, there is no better 4X available right now, and it is worth the full price of 40 dollars. If you catch this thing on sale, you would be a fool to pass it up.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
23, 2015
												As someone who cut their teeth on Master of Magic on my first PC, I can definitely recommend Age of Wonders 3 to both old fans of the genre and folks getting into it for the first time.  The clean visual look and easy to follow unit art combines well with a deeply layered strategy game that has an amazing depth of content, particularly with both DLC packages included.The top layer of the game is all about strategy - building up your empire, expanding your cities reach, marshalling a vast army of armored elves, lucky halflings, or agile tigrans and assaulting dungeons and tombs for ancient treasure while balancing your diplomacy and maintaining an alignment that may influence your neighbors opinion of you (if you even care what they think - especially if your goal is to crush them like a bug).  When you get into battle with an opposing force, the game really shines again with a powerful tactical layer - positioning your units to defend their flanks and take advantage of your enemies over-reaching become as important as fielding the proper units.  Pikes deployed against mounted cavalry works brilliantly, especially if you can get behind a spent and exhaused human Knight!  Then again, a well placed fireball can work wonders, as well.The races and classes are many and varied, and with one amazing spell or ability to research after another regardless of the combination you select at map setup you'll play for hundreds of hours before you start to see all the combinations.  From Warlords and their incredibly potent troops to Necromancers and Sorcerers with their poweful magic and mighty summons, including Dread Reapers and Eldrich Horrors, there is something here for all types of strategy gamers.The multi-player in simultaneous mode works wonders - especially if you are playing with friends on teams, it takes a long time to complete a game but it's just an amazing half a dozen hours to spend.In the end, I've probably spent as much time watching videos as I have playing it, and I am looking forward to many more years of both - there is a lot to learn, and a lot to dig into, but the basics are simple and elegant and the longeveity of the game is definitely something worth considering.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2015
												I believe the finest fantasy TBS we have at the moment.Heavily focused on epic battles, exploration and leveling up your heroes. That's where its core is! Every class and race play differently with their pros and cons so gameplay and replayability are kept alive and fresh by the "let me try this now!" factor.City management is secondary, but not irrilevant: you'll find yourself specializing cities and terraforming here and there to suit them to your strategy and playstyle.It'll completely suck you in and if you've a friend to play with it's even better! MP goes on at a VERY slow pace, especially when it's more than 3 Leaders involved, but the pause between turns gives you time to do other things like reading a book, watching a video or a movie, checking the Tome of Wonders, planning next moves and so forth... so its apparently weak spot is instead another of its great points.AI is a bit weird at times but it reacts and listens to your request and proposals pretty well. So forge alliances, betray, bribe other factions and set them at war against your opponents. Level up your Heroes, send them afar to expand your domains and rule the land with the iron grip and brute force of the Orcs! Or dwell in the underground and patiently multiply your Goblins waiting to erupt to the surface and destroy the land of men!Cleanse the earth and bring peace in all the Empire as the Leader of High Elves or forge incredible machines that will shake the ground beneath their wheels and crush your enemies as a Dwarven Dreadnought! Seriously... never had had this fun in a long time!!Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												Do not expect the deep empire management of civilization, this game's strong side is in its combat system, magic system and customization options. You can customize your own avatar and the choice of talents, class and race have significant impact to how your game will play out, allowing to pick a combination most suited to your playstyle. Or just experiment if that's your thing.As mentioned, the empire management aspects are lacking compared to the competition. Tech tree gets exhausted pretty quickly and it's pretty easy to win by overpowering the AI in early game. On the other hand this kind of setup allows for faster and more 'action' oriented multiplayer matches. However the AI is notoriously bad in terms of diplomacy and still has some bugs that make it easy to beat even on higher difficulties. Add to that an incomplete diplomatic system and the only real option to win the game outside of scripted scenarios is full on military conquest.The best part however is the combat system. Units are carefully balanced and the combat system allows to win through superior tactics against much more powerful armies... if you know what you're doing. Finding out the various tactics to take down particularly tough units is half the fun. Defending a city surrounded assaulted by a superior foe is suitably satisfying, as is taking out defenders through tactical use of the right units.Overal: Age of Wonders 3 is a Heroes of Might and Magic meets Civilization in a Tolkien-ish inspired setting. Don't get it for the empire management or you'll be disappointed. Get it for the combat and magic system and it's loads of fun.

29, 2014
												This game isn't perfect, but I think it is a good followup on the old AoW games. I really like the class system and the classes do play very differently. Magical spheres are still around though they are more of a complement to the class spells and abilities now. Race has a lot less impact than class admittedly, but there are enough differences between the races that the choice matters.  That aside, the tactical combat is very good and has some interesting additions compared to the old games.The game is in need of some patching, and could definetly use some expansions/DLC with more of the old races (Tigrans naturally) being added. One of my main annoyances however is that the unit design is fairly lazy, at least for the class units. Most theocrat and warlord units for instance are bald for all races, they could have had some variation there. Skinny hairless elven angels do not scream exalted to me. =P

												Absolutely amazing. This is definitely one of the better strategy games you get on steam. This game is on par with Civ V or  maybe even better. The combat is fun, the customization is fun, taking cities is rewarding and each game is different in its own way. The visuals are fantastic and the tactical combat is extremely well done. It rarely gets boring since all minor conflicts can be solved through an auto-calculation so it never gets tedious. Plus the auto-calculations are usually pretty fair and that's a huge plus compared to other games that have tried this feature.  If you're a fan of strategy or even just fantasy this is a must-buy. I can't believe this game isn't more popular than it is. Steam and really the entire 4x scene should have more games like this and would benefit greatly from it.

content:
, 2016
												Lovely game. I enjoyed the tutorial immensely. This is a hybrid of Heroes of Might and Magic and Civilization, 2 games that I also enjoy. I prefer the textured map of Heroes of Might and Magic rather than the flat map system of Civilizations. Being able to see the rivers, mountains, streams and the underground make for a much more interesting game. PROS1. The Zoomed In Combat SystemI love this. Combat is based on an Action Point system and is slightly better compared to similar combat systems from 4X games like Endless Legends. You have elevation, terrain, range and spells and even strategic positioning. E.g. If you were to attack an enemy Hero with 2 armies on the left and right flank, the armies will appear on the right and left flank of the enemy as well.2. Feedback ButtonI love the consideration that the developers put in for their players. While I'm sure that the developers aren't able to attend to all feedback, it is a good idea for players to give their feedback. Also, if I ever need to report bugs, this makes it easy to do. Alternatively, F12 works as well.3. Textured Map vs Flat MapYou get to see details versus a plain flat map.4. Lore and ThemeI love the Dreadnought.5. Wall ClimbingVery nice. I like the climbing of walls. It's something that's not in Civilizations or Heroes. Not that it's very useful. I'm guessing Total War has had a small impact here?6. Scout CreaturesPrety useful.7. Expanding your Territory with BuildersNot bad, but not perfect. Instead of using builders for roads and industrial upgrades, you build settlements that increase your city's domain. Compared to buying tiles with culture, it's much better. However, the builders need to be given instructions, otherwise they are pieces of junk. If you don't expand, it stands around doing nothing.8. Spells instead of TechnologyNot bad. It's thematically more interesting.9. Multiple heroes in CombatLove it, although I am unsure if hero bonuses stack on troops.CONS1. Unintuitive ClickingNo auto-pickup. You have to pick it up on your own with a left click and then place it in your inventory. Why can't you just auto-pick it up if you have inventory space?2. RegistrationPain in the ♥♥♥. I understand that you need to use it to link with GOG and Steam though.3. Equipping itemsWhy is the bow in your inventory and not held in your hand? Do you go into combat with your weapon stashed in your bag?4. Cliche RacesGoblins, Elves, Orcs, Humans, Dwarves? How much Tolkien do you want to repeat?5. No Parallel BuildsYou can only ever build 1 thing at anytime. Why can't you make an upgrade that builds 2 things at once? E.g. 2 infantry will pop up in a single turn. 6. Spellcasting in CombatIf I'm right, only 1 spell can be used per round. Having 2 heroes that can cast spells is redundant. I may have to double-check on this.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2016
A Paladin’s Review: Age of Wonders III. The Golden Realms are a Triumph of The Eternal Lords.Genre: 4X Turn-Based RPG with Empire Building and Strategy.Developed & Published by:Triumph Studios.Platform:Windows, Mac and Linux.DRM: Free Triumph Studios Account Required for Multiplayer. SteamWorks. Both Are Optional For Offline Singleplayer and HotSeat Multiplayer.Business Model: Single Purchase plus Special Edition and Two Separate Expansions. Expansions aren’t required to play with other people who own them.Base Game Gifted By Friend, Expansions + Special Edition Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged version on A Paladin Without A Crusade because frankly it was too long to fit here.[kingisaaclinksr.com]


YouTube™ Video: A Paladin’s Review: Age of Wonders III. The Golden Realms are a Triumph of The Eternal Lords. 

			Views: 156		

			Don't want to watch? Read the written version here: http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2016/11/10/a-paladins-review-age-of-wonders-iii-the-golden-realms-are-a-triumph-of-the-eternal-lords/ I'm truly...		

Initial Overall ThoughtsTwo years have passed since I was gifted the base game of AOW and purchased the expansions along the way. I’ve put in over 100 hours of play in the single player campaigns, online and play-by-email multiplayer modes. I’d say I spent most of my time in online multiplayer. From the get-go, I was already enjoying this entry and I think it’s for the simple reason that there aren’t a lot of 4X strategy titles like this on the market. The blending of RPG, 4X and Empire Building mechanics is still rare despite the resurgence of turn-based games in recent years. Age of Wonders seems keen on proving that it still deserves its place.This is the kind of strategy game I like to sink an entire Sunday afternoon and evening into. Where time simply goes by completely unawares. I get sucked into managing my noble empire of good Humans against the undead scourge of the evil Necromancer (aka: Managarmr). That one-more-turn addiction is ever present and I’ve burned many happy days trying to explore, determine the next resource to take over, training armies and expanding the empire as best as I could. With the random procedural generation, each match will feel unique, even when playing on the same map settings. Just the experience of roleplaying a fantasy character, that’s in charge of any number of types of empires,was engaging on its own. However, maybe that’s the roleplayer in me talking. Evil, neutral, chaotic, elemental, destructive, good or peace-seeking, the game allows you to build your own experience and try to play to the conditions you set for yourself. I’ll explain more in the mechanics below.AOW3 is about victory through expansion, fighting and conquest. As the leader of a powerful empire, you should always be exploring to find hidden treasures and places to setup new cities. To expand your empire as quickly as possible by taking over resource buildings and conquering your foes. You should move quickly or else you’ll get left behind. The basic structure of your empire are towns, cities and outposts. These places let you build units, upgrades and more that grant access to more powerful units, increasing your revenue streams and giving permanence to your empire. Which you’ll need for the army and taking over rival Throne Cities. Even with the alternate victory conditions brought about in the expansions, military prowess is what the game favors for victory. The diplomacy system is simplistic. It gives the very basic functions of diplomacy (declare war, allow armies through territories, etc) and that’s about it. It also provides a way to talk to players if needed. Otherwise, the AI doesn’t use it very well and trying to barter with it is near impossible. Side note, you could technically win a victory through peaceful means, but that would require forging alliances with other players who win the game for you. It’s not that enjoyable nor encouraged by the game or myself.Leader, Heroes and Units ExaminationEach player controls an empire led by a Leader, a powerful character with vast control over their elemental and racial magic. These leaders can function in the role of a supporting hero or go on the offensive in the front lines with spells and abilities. They can also ride mounts, equip weapons, items & armor as well as level up. During the game they are casting spells that can affect cities or other units as well as learning new spells through knowledge research. There are plenty of spells to learn from not only based on their class but their specialization and race. They are your most powerful units but they are also a potentially crippling weakpoint of your empire. If taken out, they can no longer cast their spells, research is stopped dead and whatever existing spells are cancelled. Leaders will return in a couple of days at their home base but that leaves the empire vulnerable to attack and can slow everything down to a crawl. Generally, it’s a good idea to not lose them. You can completely customize their appearance, race, class and specialties or pick from several defaults included in the game. The leader builder in the game is definitely good if not the most powerful I’ve ever seen. I’ve created several unique heroes and always liked coming up with new ideas for mine.Final ThoughtsAge of Wonders III combines empire building, role-playing mechanics and turn-based strategy into one glorious mix. I don’t regret the 100+ hours I’ve sunken into it. It’s got great multiplayer support and a pretty decent multiplayer community to go along with it. The sheer amount of content that you can find is incredible as well. I haven’t even touched on everything I could have in this review. I’m going to keep playing Age of Wonders 3 in the future even if I do have reservations about its pacing. What AOW3 does right far outweighs what it does wrong and it’s been a hell of a memorable experience. I just wish the early game’s battles were more interesting and less one sided. I additionally wish magic was a little less restrictive and more interesting in the early game as well. The game only really seems to get interesting once you hit mid-to-late game levels. But maybe that’s just me. The RNG system is robust and fair along with the game’s overall balance giving players a more-or-less equal chance to win. At least, from what I can tell of my 100 hour experience.Far and away Age of Wonders III is one of my top strategy games of all time. It’s memorable for all the right reasons despite its flaws and shortcomings. I heartily recommend it for both new and experienced 4X strategy players. This is well worth giving a look.Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
13, 2015
												Now that I've completed both campaigns, I would have expected to be strongly recommending this game to others.Unfortunately, I have a real love/hate relationship with this game. Much of the game is great - the grpahics, interface, music and basic gameplay elements. You certainly won't lack for gameplay, the two campaigns took me well over 100 hours to finish, although I never use auto combat so battles made up most of that time.The hate part comes from the lack of documenation and a few really terrible scenarios in the campaigns. All games should have a manual, especially games this complex, but there is no manual.Three of twelve scenarios in the campaigns are awful, some of the worst scenario designs I have encountered in decades of playing strategy games, the rest of the scenarios are lots of fun. One is horrible because it has a hidden timer. The other two, the last scenarios in each campaign are horrible because they are mind numbingly frustrating. You have far too many enemies to fight, your basic task is to fight two leaders and attack them with a particular hero. Finding the two leaders is a slow, boring process. It's an idiotic idea which pretty much ruined both campaigns for me. If you are lucky you won't have to play these scenarios, it depends on choices you make earlier in the campaigns.I do recommend this game if you are willing to put up with some frustration.

content:
, 2014
												The game shows alot of promise, and I was totally sold on it from the trailers. But truth be told, the actuall combat mechanics and AI leaves much to be desired. The different races all play the same, with mostly the same units to choose from, and it doesnt help that you can absorb any race into your empire and as such actaully play all races in one single game. The different classes have some different spells and units to choose from, but spells in general are a bit of a letdown. You generally use the same two spells over and over again since there is no point in using anything else. Same with units, some units are way OP and when the enemy only build these units there is no point in creating diverse armies for the fun of it. Units dont have many special abilities, and the lower tiers become obsolete quickly. One cool thing is that you can absorb the "special" NPC races such as dragons, giants and undead into your empire if you take one of their towns. On a strategic note, you need to learn how to use your units to their full extent, and pay atention to flanking since this plays a major role in combat. Unfortenetly units with lots of HP generally have high dmg aswell, so using week dps units are just not an option in the long run, bigger is always better in this game. Verdict: Has some good ideas, and the game looks good. But after playing one custom map against the computer, you have basiclly experienced all there is to it. So good fun for 3-5 hours, then you forget about it.

												Well, what can I say?♥♥♥♥. I lost whole, WHOLE damn night because of "another turn syndrome".There is no better fantasy strategy game out there. Heroes of Might and Magic (the new ones) would wish they were that good.This game not only did what the first Age of Wonders did right, it does everything better.Battles of epic proportions, upgradable heroes and minions, a great ammount of various races and units plus specialities, spells, freedom to create your own towns, deciding what to specialize at, using terrain tactically, flanking and joining several armies around the target to fight with 2 or 3 heroes at the same time... That's just from the top of my head. This game is a real time stealer...With those kinds of games I am usually hard to please, but this time I am shocked at how good this is.Unlike the first games it is not only good techically, but story-wise as well. Keeps you entertained for sure.As far as fantasy strategy games go? This is 10/10 right there.

content:
y 18, 2015
												In brief: A game with a fantastic concept that lacks the depth and balance to hold the player's attention.In not so brief:I was really excited about this game. I saw some gameplay and got it on the Steam Winter Sale after waiting forever for the price to drop. I was excited by the combination of strategic overworld combined with tactical combat and thought it would make for dynamic and immersive gameplay. To go with the Civilization comparison I had always wished the combat there was more detailed / more engaging and I thought this was the answer. Unfortunately I fails to live up to expectations.You choose class and race and those determine what "special units" you get and some specialized bonuses and abilities. Unfortunately, the special units are little more than reskins of the same basic types. You have infantry, calvary, and archers. And your specialized units are only "special" in a few details. Once you get to mid-game you've figured out the most efficient way to conduct your battles in the tactical map and so just rinse-and-repeat through the entire late-game. You end up hitting "auto-combat" more and more because it's no longer exctiting to spend 7 minutes to crush some bandits. And at that ponit you're no longer even playing the tactical portion. Every tactical map is effectively the same, and so each battle progresses the same way.There is no other choice than "crush all your enemies in combat". While in Civ you can win through economics, diplomacy, or culture, in AoW III it is ONLY through conquest. Well that's fine, right? Because you came to play a fantasy strategic/tactical combat game. That's what I thought. But this affects the AI a LOT. Peace treaties are a joke. The AI will propose them, and then break them only a few turns later. There's no real penalty for doing so and in the end they have no other choice. They HAVE to fight you at some point. So forming alliances in game doesn't really work. As a result, the AI is pumping out units at a high rate. Which just turns the game into an arms race. You don't have time to focus on the unique terraforming spells or anything that's not directly combat related. It's just a sprint to get to late-game units so you can stand up to the AI. Which means you probably get there before even exploring the entire map. So the late game is dominated by just cleaning up the rest of your opponents. Sure, now you have the flexibility to play with terraforming or something, but why bother? The game is almost over.One final thing is that some of the background game mechanics are broken. Empire Happiness is notably problematic. You gain happiness for a number of things but most importantly for conquering other cities. You lose happiness for such things as losing cities. Happiness determines how well your troops perform in combat. The result of this is that once you get an enemy on their heels it's lights out. It becomes a runaway effect where you just get better and better and they get worse and worse. Instead of long campaigns being tiring for your troops, it's almost invigorating. Additionally, your throne city is EVERYTHING. As in, if you lose that, you lose it all. Literally. Keeping your throne city is a victory requirement. So you can't turtle in a lesser city off to the side to make a brilliant comeback later. If you lose that it's game over. So the easiest way to defeat an opponent is to walk past all of their other cities, go right to their throne, and take it. The end.I could say more but this review is already overly long. I really, deeply wish I could recommend this game, but it's simply not worth it. Like I said a fantastic concept that falls flat when it comes to execution. If you want to play a turn-based strategy game, play Civ. If you want to play a turn based tactical game, play X-COM. If you want to play a fusion of the two, wait for something better to come along.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												This new iteration to the Age of Wonders franchise combines the empire management of the Civilization games and the turn based, hexagonal combat system of the Heroes of Might and Magic series perfectly. The world full of vast biomes and areas to explore has a lot to offer. From sending your armies into a crypt to find a dragon defended by dragonkin and skeletons to sending your army against the Elvish Arch Druid army, only for him to call upon the Forest God to decimate your musketeers. This game offers amazing customization options as well, from creating your character and his looks to choosing his race, his class, his attributes and his spells. All of these options affect how you will play the game. Will you become a Dwarf Arch Druid and heal the land around your empire to reap the awards of a bountiful Harvest? Or will you become a Dragonkin Mage and call down fire and plague and destroy your rival's lands? These spells and skills also affect the combat in the game. Your heroes will have one time spells to use to decimate a particulary powerful creature or even call up a large random creature, which turns out to be a poisonous death adder. Overall, this game is a great source of fun and enjoyment and I can see myself putting many more hours into this game.

content:
y 6, 2016
												Age of Wonders III is a very combat centered turn based strategy game with a fantasy setting where magic can turn the tide of battle just as much as steel. Many people try to compare this game to Civilization V, in respect to that I respond. Age of Wonders III does use a city based system in part to produce an army and procure territory to gain resources. However, in the defense of that mechanic there are options of using Summoned units, Inns, and rewards gained from battle or clearing quests to earn an army. Some of those features are clearly not in Civilization V. For me the better game series to compare to comes from the Real Time Strategy games known as Warcraft (Age of Wonders III) and Starcraft (as opposed to Civ V). If you ever played Warcraft III you might remember the times of having a Hero unit that could (and often did) become more powerful than most other units of your army, sometimes more powerful than a small handful of units on their own.Age of Wonders III uses a Hero system in a similar concept as Turn Based Strategy game. Your heroes level up, earn abilities. You can quest, battle, or even forge your own gear (non-campaign on the forging bits) for your heroes to use in combat. Heroes can die, and when they die they drop all the items they had on them. But you do not have to say goodbye to them forever because there are ways in game to revive them, powerful revival magic (instead of hero shrines from Warcraft 3).TLDR: Ultimately, if you play the game for a single player experience you will find enjoyment in the campaigns, and for a time in the solo scenarios, random maps, and various play styles. However, combat will quickly become tedious and repetative. Against the A.I. I recommend using Auto-Battle most the time, but the true glory of the Manual Battles is when you can fight against a Human Opponent using either Online, LAN, or Hotseat as a multi-player turn based game.Quick Notes:- I recommend Turn Based with a 3 minute turn timer for small groups.(turn timer incase people forget to hit end turn)- There is the option to use Simultaneous turns (but it can feel choppy, and it can lead to logisitic problems for battle prep on the strategic map)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2014
												Age of Wonders 3 is a turn-based fantasy 4X strategy game focused on combat rather than empire building. As such, it has more in common with Master of Magic and Heroes of Might and Magic III than with Civilizations 5.The base game provides two different and quite long campaigns featuring branching paths and different endings, a few pre-generated scenarios, and a random map generator with a lot of map and game options to customize your games to your liking.Multiplayer is present and alive with the possibility to play with people who own the GOG version, meaning the community is not divided.You start a game by customizing your leader by choosing his race and class between 6 different races and 6 different races, amounting to 36 different initial combinations, with each race and class having distinct spells and characteristic, providing them different optimal gameplay while still being homogeneous enough to keep things balanced. To further specialize your leader, you can also chose between 8 specialization options, such as Water adept, Fire adept, Explorer, etc.The game is extremely fun to play and the combat system is excellent in both concept and execution. Add to that different units and spells interacting together dynamics and you get really epic battles that never feel like they are dragging on.Golden Realms Expansion:The first expansion pack adds one new race, two new specializations, a new campaign, new scenarios, new units, new spells, new mechanics, and new map options, turning the game from great to amazing.Highly recommended!!!

content:
y 12, 2016
												For strategy game maniacs such as myself I can recommend this at full price. However, if you are new to the gendre I would rather wait till discount or buy some other strategy game first. It should be noted though that I've only played multiplayer so my recommendation is solely based on that.If roughly compared to other 4x strategy games I've played I would say it's better than Endless Legend but worse than Civilization V, and quite par on par with Endless Space. This is of course my personal opinion, and coming from someone who rarely touches single player aspect of strategy games and plays almost solely against friends in multiplayer.The little experience I've had with AI is that it's somewhat repeative, stupid and predictable. For example if AI is defending a city it tends to charge trough the gates giving attacking player easy win. But this is very common for games (that's why I play almost solely against human opponents) and Age of Wonders still does better job with AI than for example Civilization V.

content:
ber 18, 2014
												This game is very entertaining. The way the combat works, is an interesting twist to typical HOMM style.  There are not any creature stacks and units due full damage regardless of health until they die.  Along with that, probably the best feature is being able to pull multiple armies (attacker and defender to a combined total of 6) into a single battle.  If you are looking for a combat focused turn based strategy, do not overlook this.Pros:Small to large scale battles.Lots of Hero customization (talents and itemcrafting).Game looks good.Haven't had any crashes or bugs.Campaign story is enganging.The voice acting is very good.Cons.The AI is brutally difficulty even on normal.The tutorial doesn't tell you much.Could take too long for multiplayer (I've had some battles take an hour plus).Not much of a diplomacy system (fine by me but others may be sad).Every time I go to load I get asked if I want to save (why?).Third party drm (can do single player without logging in though).

												So you like 4x games? You like the exploring, expanding, exterminating, and exploiting? You also like turn based games? Well then you have come to the right game. This game revolves around empire building and toppling enemy empires. Pretty straight forward, but each game can take up to four hours to complete. The bigger the map the longer. Me and my friend did a very large map(largest you can get) in a two vs two. We won, but it took us at least 20+ hours to finish it. You found a city, build an army explore some dungeon areas to get some gear for heroes. Build bigger armies and vanquish your opponents. I would recommend getting the DLC even though it is pricey. It makes it more fun to spice up the game with more classes and races to play as.

content:
ber 2, 2016
												This was my first Age of Wonders game. I've played tons of HoMM up to 3, but no Civ or any other 4x games. Overall I like the game and recommend it. It took me five restarts of the first campaign before I "got" it, so you might need to be patient.The story is indepth, if you enjoy that (admittedly I started skipping it a few missions in - just wanted to play). The graphics are great. So far I've made it through most of the Elven campaign. You get to play several different heroes. Each one has many different skills to choose. You'll find loot along the way that you equip on your heroes. There are several different quests for each map, some optional.There's lots of exploring, including underground. Lots of fighting as well. The battles are hex based, similar to tabletop games. One thing you'll learn is you'll want at least two armies when attacking. The battles are strategic - obstacles that cause line of sight penalties, flanking, hero spells, siege attacks if someone is in a city, support-group spells and abilites, etc.On the postive, I enjoy exploring the map and battling, although I auto battle a lot because it's quicker. The graphics are nice. I like the loot you pick up. As someone who's never played an AoW game before, I do find the AI challenging, even on Easy. If the AI has an advantage, it will attack your army. Any time you leave a city undefended, the AI will take it. And it seems very smart in the battles; it doesn't make dumb moves.For the negatives, I find the game repetitive. I build up my cities pretty much identical each map. So far all of the maps have just been "Defeat the other players." Manual battles can be lengthy which makes it tough if you have limited playing time. There is such an advantage to being in a city for a fight that you can trap the AI in a city as you buildup other armies to attack. I've run into this repeatedly - having to track down "turtled" enemy heroes in cities and build up large enough armies to win.There are some negatives for me, but I do still enjoy playing the game. I'm almost finished with the Elven campaign and hoping the other campaign offers more than just "Defeat all enemies" every map.

content:
er 25, 2015
												If you like 4x type games this is a good one, if you like rpgs.... well if you like 4x its a good one. But seriously a good solid game. If you want a Civ type game is a fantasy setting this is one of the best ones out there. Lots of customization and depth. Very detailed character creation and great mechanics for customizing the play to your own style. Want to sneak up on your enemies? Smite them from afar? Smash them with giant machines? Blast them with terrible magics? Negotiate with them (coward... jk)?  you can do it here.First the basics-Graphics- immersive and well executed, solid if not flashy. 8/10Gameplay- Easy to play and learn. It has good depth when you want to dive down into the mechanics. 9/10Music/SF- Nothing jarring or off putting, but nothing epic either. Always switched to my own tunes fairly quickly. 5/10Content- Lots of good stuff on the map, fun to explore. Plenty of scenarios and several main campaigns, but no really engaging stories, I find I go to randoms maps as I come back to the game. as a RPG 4/10, as a 4X 9/10.Ok so now lets look at this as a 4x-eXplore- This is probably my favorite part of the game. Many and various encounters on the map lead to a lot of variety in gameplay. This has a feel like Heros of M&M 3, with maps full of goodies. eXpand- Not really part of the game. Oh sure you grow your city and maybe build a couple more, but there is no real benefit or mechanic for the massive empire in this game. eXploit- Magic always makes this fun. I really enjoy the way it lets you manipulate the environment of the game. Lots of ways to customize your character to fit your style. eXterminate- This is were this game shines. It has good combat mechanics that make each battle different, but also allows you to turn things over to the AI when you get too bogged down late game. Every race and every class bring their own unit types and style to combat, making it extremely variable and challenging.In the end I recommend this game. If you saw RPG and came for that turn around now, but otherwise a good game and worth the price.

content:
6, 2014
												Having played most fantasy turn based strategy games since Master of Magic, I can honestly say that Age of Wonders III is a worthy addition to the genre.  It looks and sounds great, runs smoothly, and (unlike most of the venerable fantasy TBS,) has an AI that actually shows up and tries to win.  However, if you go into the game with the same attitude that you might have in the older games, you might not have much fun.Age of Wonders III is about conquest and fighting.  Everything you do in this game must drive you to this goal.  You cannot explore the map lazily looking for secrets, build armies of "fluff" because dwarf axemen are cool, or waste your mana terriforming cities when the enemy is at the gates.  In this game you have to constantly be on the lookout for ways to exploit the map, and for enemies to come out of nowhere.  By the end of the game, the surviving empires may be two giant war machines endlessly pumping units at each other from across the map (thankfully, rally points have been added.)  The last battles will, in drawn out cases, consist entirely of massive stacks of the most powerful units.  This may or may not be okay with people.I'll admit, I'm the kind of person who wants his last army to look like something from Lord of the Rings, just a huge mass of swords and bows being thrown at a huge mass of orcs.  Sadly, that will rarely happen, as this huge mass of men would just be slaughtered by a smaller mass of dragons, giants, war machines or those horrible Manticore Riders.  Indeed, I was a bit frustrated when my army of dwarven crossbowmen behind a stone wall was slaughtered by a handful of these units.  I guess what I'm trying to say with this is that this game will not make you feel like you are really leading an army of fantasy creatures in a great war.  Neither does a game of Magic the Gathering, but it sure is fun.On the subject of the AI, if you leave it alone, then you will see it turning into a massive war machine with the aforementioned rallypoints and Tier 4 units slogging across the map.  AI Knight has learned a few things since Age of Wonders II.  While it is still possible to see some tactical blunders (suiciding flyers for example) it puts up a better fight than most without extra help.  Admittedly, I haven't seen if it gets any, but I haven't noticed anything from it that made me call foul.If I have to criticize it, it would be that most games play pretty much the same, requiring a similar strategy from the player to win based on race and class choice, and the layout of the map, while it may throw occaisional curveballs at you, has little to do with how things progress.  But in that criticism I just described many games that are perfectly fine, as is this one (Heroes of Might and Magic series might be the exception there, but look how good the last one of those was...)  The fun in a game like that is to optimize that strategy to perfect it, while someone across the battlefield from you tries to counter it.  The game's AI does not forgive you if you screw up. Really if I wanted to throw out things I'd like, it'd be some degree of city specialization (choose between buildings rather than just build everything everywhere,) more options for creating items and creating/leveling characters, and maybe some map structures that can change the course of the game (special unit recruitment, buffs to city created units such as Master of Magics "Adamantium Deposits") and so on.  Also, with all the terriforming and terrain changing options, I want terrain to mean more to me during the game.  Maybe I'm just not paying attention to it, but right now, I only terriform for a little extra gold from cities and for looks.  Its still cool though, changin the world into a frozen wasteland or a sweltering jungle.  I do miss the Shadow World though, and the Dark Elves, and the Nomads, hell, even the Halflings, but I am sure I'll see them all again.There will be DLC, and I will pay for it.  The game world can only get bigger and better, and Triumph really seems to be putting all their effort into it.tldr: Its very fun.  And competitive.  Its not building an epic empire in a grand story, its all about stomping your enemies into the dirt.  And it ends like Clash of the Titans except with more Titans.  Its not Age of Wonders II, but Age of Wonders II didn't magically disappear or anything.  And you can make a Dwarf Succubus.  Seriously.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												Review as of the Eighth of May, 2014.After about 60-70 hours in total with recorded time and offline time in this four X game, I have to commend it.As with every 4X game, this one has a distinct love of two of them, eXploit and eXterminate. Let's start with that.The command, unlike some other games, namely Fallen Enchantress, which is the main comparrison I'll be making, is rather dull. It takes about 25-70 turns, depending on what's in its domain, to complete the city entirely, and each city has to make that trek and the only real thing that changes it is the Raze, Plunder and Migrate options for each city, which is a nice touch, since each race has its own benefits.  Compared to Fallen Enchantress, though, the cities feel... Dull. It's the same path each time, and once you get all your class specific units, the entire war units tree is useless. One main problem I have with it, and this is a personal quipe, but oh well, is that the cities just suddenly... get taken over. Anything above a city I'm practically yelling at the screen with the general rage when a group of SCOUT units, which literally are so easy to kill that a tier four takes 1 damage to them, takes over your throne city/any other metropolis. That was a major turn off for me.Now, onto the war section. The combat is probably the most fun I've had in a 4X. It's really slick, it carries weight, and the seiges are fun. The general feel of the units are amazing, with specific combinations practically winning seiges and battles. The units all have unique rolls on the battlefield, some are tanks that don't deal much damage, or a "Give them the plague!" units that makes whatever they attack weaker. And one of my favorite, and at the same time least favorite, mechanics is that each battlefield consists of six hexes that each unit on takes part in. But then comes the little problem of top teir units being stacked and being literally impossible in a city to dislodge. And the units that aren't inside the gates on the map spawning on the battlefield suddenly inside it. That irritated me that you couldn't just send an army to fight one another. But, despite the units unique to each faction, I kept feeling the same feeling of "These are rather generic units" at the end of the game, since every end game unit tends to be what you'd expect. They should flesh it out a lot more and add either entire unit customization or just athestic customization. Oh. And heroes are practically useless unless you totally defend them with everything, since they're so low health and defence.The explore and expand elements are generally how it feels in other games, use the explore to get loot and make more of the same generic city over the map. And don't even get me started on how useless the neautral city AI are. They're there for one purpose: Be conquered!All in all, though, I'd say it's an amazing game with its problems that can be fixed with just a smidge of effort, or if a modder is willing, they could always fix it.Overall opinion: For me, personally, I like more diplomancy and less masses of war units everywhere. 8/10. I recommend it, I got my money's worth out of it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I give this game a 8 out of 10.The game reminds you strongly of Heroes of Might and Magic.  Your character travels the map, explores locations, and takes controll of resource points.  Combat isn't as developed as HoMM.  Your troops are deployed randomly and your find yourself really missing being able to line up your troops as you see fit.  Also lacks the variety of HoMM's tactical combat options for your units.The game also strongly reminds you of Elemental Fallen enchantress.  You can send out units to colonize and expand your realm.  Building different buildings expands the zone of controll for each city.  It falls a little short of the Elemental comparison with the lack of RPG elements and the variety of items to equip your character with.The storyline for the two campaigns is decent, the single female voice actress does a great job, but you find yourself wishing for a few animated cutscenes to spice things up.  Each mission is more or less the same.  Build up your troops and take out your enemies.  It can get a little stale after about 20 hours though.

content:
9, 2014
												There have been a lot of new entries in the Fantasy 4X Strategy genre in recent years. For a long time though it seems like the genre has peaked with classics like Master of Magic, and Heroes of Might an Magic 3. The latter being a personal favorite of mine. Now after a long wait we are getting games that are really good again like Fallen Enchantress, and Warlock. Age of Wonders 3 however is probably my new favorite out of all of them.You can tell when playing it that the designer has probably played all of the games I mentioned above, and more. The game takes many good ideas of those titles incorporating in with some good ideas of it's own. The result feels really solid. Almost like a greatest hits album of the genre. It's important to know though that the title is focused more on the competitive element. This isn't an empire builder like Civ where you can sit in a corner, and focus on culture or something. It's built as a war game. Those that go into understanding that, and craving it will have a better time.

content:
, 2014
												This game is a rare treat. I was looking for a game to scratch my "Disciples: Sacred Lands" itch and found a game that played like a hybrid of the aforementioned itch and the later games of the "Civilization" franchise. Gameplay is enjoyable and well developed, but not so complicated that it detracts from the over-all experience. Animations such as the number of soldiers in a unit being a visible "health bar" for the overall unit is a nice touch, as are the animations in general. I have had much enjoyment watching my Dwarven Musketeers open fire against the flank of an Orc Spearmen unit. Or my Elven Longbowmen fire wave after wave of arrows into their foes. The lore is well done, and not too heavy or crying out for your undivided attention, but there is enough there to get you into the game's mechanics, whilst leaving room for DLC and add on campaigns and scenarios which will help this already interesting game stay fresh. A good soundtrack with a variety of fantasy inspired tracks doesn't hurt either, I have found myself humming along to the soundtrack on more than one occasion. A privilege in strategy games previously only enjoyed by Paradox. Multiplayer is remincent of other games in the genre. I would recommend playing it with close friends, or people in the same room as big maps with strangers would be a bold, and overly optimistic state of affairs.All in all a good experience fully worth the money advertised. I fully expect many hours to be lost to this little gem and would not lament that fact.

content:
ber 24, 2014
												I never played the original, but I loved Age of Wonders II. So coming into this as a fan of AoW2, my expectations were high, and I honestly wasn't disappointed. I love this game for so many reasons, from leader creation and customization to the way your race tints the special units your class affords you. The game is visually beautiful and fairly well-paced, and the random map generator has always delivered a world I genuinely enjoyed exploring and conquering.AoW3 suits a number of play styles and victory conditions, all of which you can toggle on or off. The battles require thought and planning a little more than raw power. A number of weak units can take down a smaller number of more powerful units if you position everyone correctly and use just the right spells at the right times. I get a genuine sense of pride every time I successfully bring down a powerful enemy army.There are, of course, a few things that could stand to be improved. I'd like more customization options as far as hair is concerned, and there are some lighting issues and minor clipping problems on some of the unit models. However, all of these issues are superficial and very easy to overlook. I don't find they detract from my experience at all.Excellent game if you enjoy fantasy, strategy or 4X games, and an absolutely superb game if you enjoy all three!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												At a younger age I played "Master of Magic" by Microprose. Loved that game and spent countless hours playing it. When Age of Wonders came along, I had a ton of fun with that as well. Shadow magic and Age of Wonders two were also a lot of fun. This one however, I didn't really like. They've taken a step away from the high fantasy setting and tried to incorporate steam punk into the game, which in turn makes it a mish mash of two different settings. They should have gone with the original concept or simply made a steam punk game and call it something else. The previous games did have some hints of steam punk with the dwarven faction, but this time around it's all over the place and magic feels like a secondary thought in a game that's supposedly about magic.The story isn't really that good, just a repetition of previous installments, but not performed as well and kind of boring.The game is to it's core the same as previous games, but the i.e. lack of diversity between the races is gone, now instead it is based on "classes" what type of units you get. It's not a bad game but I was expecting more of a third installment. Magic doesn't feel as useful as previous games, other than perhaps some very late game summons that pretty much instant win the game for you. There's a ton of loot for your heroes, which is quite nice (but feels over the top at times, i.e. there is a spell where you can summon eggs that turn into mounts and I just spammed that spell until I got the best mounts in the game for all my heroes) and heroes are still very useful addition to your armies. I liked the introduction of mounts for heroes, that affected how they move both in the world and tactical map (even gives some stats). The music is as always good, could have used a few more tracks though. While it might seem like I am bashing the game, I'm not, it simply wasn't what I expected it to be. If you enjoyed the previous AoW games you should give it a try, I played through both sides on the original AoW III, but didn't feel like it was worth my time playing the expantions/dlc, I'd rather just give the original games another go.

content:
er 21, 2015
												This is my favorite game right now.  It has the best of expected stratagy game features, and extends the standard by including features that were missing in other empire building games.You can not only choose your leaders, but you can customize there face, hair, clothes. You can also pick the scene background for there leader screen.  You can also decide on the pose. very sweet.  I like the feelling of entering the buildings on the map.  I really like being able to move the pieces during tacticle battles. The unit banners have the health meter, so I pick on the weakest guy.Naval battles actually take place on the water, and "Embarked" units are standing on boats while they fight.  The research takes place from a spell book, which is cool. The mini map is more custamizable than I was used to. The landscape textures are beautiful.Zooming out on the strategic map and having the map become a "cloth" map with drafted geographic features, makes this seem even more emersive.  It is very similar to the map in the end pages of "The Hobbit".Speaking of fantasy, the realm and genre one has come to expect from fantasy rpgs is well represented.From undead, to will-o-whisps. Mermaids and Krakens; Kobolds, and Dragons.  Treasure, gold, mana, and Hero pick ups.I had gotten fairly good at my usual stratagy war game, so I am humbled at how involved the added calculations and stats, the RPG world encompasses.  Good bad, Creation, destruction; the 4 elements; Arch Druids compared to dreadnaughts, or necromancers.So much fun! So much to "get into"The single most excelent awsome feature is the Modding Support.Import your blender models! Download the Rigged models from the developer! Extend the Resources that are already in the game! Customize the story line.Linked maps in a custom campaign.  Program quests! Build underground worlds! The creation Engine alone is worth every pennie I spent, (My goblin leader is Pennie the Pincher)

content:
ry 27, 2016
												This game is great whether you're a fan of the series, a fan of strategy games, or just a newcomer to these kind of games. Learning the gameplay might take a tad bit but when you start playing you'll find yourself bargaining time away just so you can play one more turn. The single player is pretty much where most people start, in order to learn the game mechanics and the game does that pretty well, by the time I got to the thrid level I was already building proper armies, upgrading cities, and destroying other empires. The game's AI is smart even on easy and you will find them hitting your weak points if you underestimate them while the hardest difficulty pushes you to use everything in your power to win, also although you can build alliances with the AI it is actually very hard to do so because most of the time they're in it for themselves but then again so are we so peace most of the time will not be in your options. You can also fight the battles yourself on a field but after awhile I just kept using auto battle unless it was a battle that I needed to be won then I took control but do know that one level can take a long time to complete because you'll be managing your cities, planning strategies for the future, or something else which will take time unless you're blitzing all the time. The music really is well made, the graphics are great, the multiplayer is fun and in a nutshell this game is very entertaining

content:
20, 2016
												This is a game that makes me look up and look at the clock and realise that 7 hours of my life has just passed by and it is suddenly light outside and oh god I need to sleep before I have to go to work and oh alright then, just one more turn and then I will defintiely go to bed... Stylistically it is a cartoony version of games such as Heroes of Might and Magic where you control a Hero and their own faction of fantasy scamps out to do valiant battle against other assorted fantasy tropes and critters. But under the cheery colourful exterior there is a very good game that, although with limitations, scratches almost all of my fantasy strategy empire building rpg itches. The RPG style Hero levelling and item system is well executed. The empire building is decent. The battles can be pretty fun and sometimes even quite challenging. The diplomacy is about as good as any other 4X game I've played and not as awful as some of them although I have yet to try to win diplomatically and so I am not sure if that is even an option. I have not played AoW 1 or 2 so I have no idea if they are better or worse than this installment but as I said, I think this one is addictive good fun.Now I feel that there is room for improvement. The late game is a bit of a boring grind; as your cities expand they all turn out a bit samey. The AI is not terrible and I have been beaten by it a few times but I wish they would actually do a bit of empire building on its own: they never build roads or forts for example. Perhaps it is better against human players but as I have no friends I have yet to experience that aspect of the game.All in all, if you like your 4X's but feel that CIV V doesn't feature enough ogres, imps or kobold minions then you should defintiely give this title a go. Also the two first expansions are good additions that in my opinion adds a lot of essential content to the vanilla game so maybe wait for a sale to get the bundle. Just a tip.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Grading Scale:10 - Masterpiece9 - Amazing8 - Great7 - Good6 - Okay5 - Mediocre4 - Bad3 - Terrible2 - Abomination1 - UnplayableGame: Age of Wonders IIISummary: Turn-based strategy game with some RPG elements and a fantasy setting.Pros:Combat- Refreshing and fun for a turn based strategy game. Although some flaws are evident (will go over it in the "cons" section). Combat takes place in a battlefield that takes into account the type of terrain you were on when combat was initiated. You can move your units around and place them in strategic areas around the field.Character Customization- Able to customize your hero with different hairstyles and certain cosmetic options such as armor and head pieces. RPG Elements- Able to equip your hero with items that are obtained throughout the world. You can also level your hero and have him/her learn new spells and moves. Among these units are mounts which really give your hero a unique feel.Units- Each unit is unique and inspired. Although you cannot customize your units the same way you can your hero, they each have their own unique abilities and appearance.Cons:Limited Victories: Although diplomacy is possible, the style of the game begs for a conquest win. The resources at your disposal for any other type of victories are simply not worth the effort. It's a lot of fun to just stomp through everything with your unique armies.Repetitiveness- After playing for a while. Combat can get a bit tedious to a point where you just find yourself skipping it altogether. Once that happens, the rest of the game just doesn't hold up. Combat is the fun part of this game, not so much the diplomacy.Verdict: Fun turn-based strategy game with a fun twist on combat that suffers from repetitiveness. The hero development, different class system and customization adds for a unique experience everytime you play the game.Score: 7

content:
2, 2014
												Fallen Enchantress, Eat your heart out.This 4X Fantasy game allows for a deep level of customization that captures the creativity of Fallen Enchantress while providing a more aesthetically pleasing, polished experience. Diplomatic and overworld gameplay remains similar to the Civilization series, while not quite as robust. It does make up for it with its level of creative control. Create your own civilization leader from a host of classes and racial combinations. Both your class and race affect the type of units your empire will have access to. If you play a rogue, depend on having stealth units, assassins and the like. Play a dreadnaught? Youll have rifleman and steam tanks. A warlord? How does having a legion of berserkers sound? While you cant directly modify individual units like fallen enchantress, the sheer vareity at your disposal makes that irrelavant.If youre looking for a high fantasy themed civilization style 4X game with RPG elements, look no further.

content:
6, 2016
												Very good game with alot of content. Especially the random maps are good (with lots of sliders to tune it to your liking incase you would want that), but the campaigns are also decent and there are loose scenario maps. Keep in mind though that while this is tagged as a 4x game, the combat part (turn based) is dominant and leveling up your hero and units is very important too. In short combat and exploration are really important.I highly recommend buying the game with the 2 expansions Golden Realm and Eternal Lords. Not only are new classes, races and specialisations added, some addional gameplay features are added and new ways to win.+ lots of possible combinations by picking your race and your class and spell specialisations. E.g. a sorcerer that summons whole armies, or a necro that has undead armies, or a dreadnought that has many machines. + be dark (plunder villages and kill of whole races), gray or good (e.g. helping villages with quests so they will join your empire or as vassals), based on actions and not race. Do whatever you like. Also several decisions in the storyline that you can make. + rich maps filled neutral ctities, hideouts, dungeons, recources, neutral places that give bonuses to nearby cities, tavern to hire units, etc. etc.  Lots of places to level up and gain loot. Also secundary quests. + The random map generator is one of the best I have ever seen. + lots of units and quite a bit of buildings and upgrades for villages/cities.+ the bigger your empire with a race and the longer you have it, the more race bonuses you will get (you pick between upgrades).+ all units can rank up which give them interesting abilities and add lots of tactics. With your leader and heroes you can pick between quite a bit upgrades/abilities per level up.+ lots of items, spells and abilities.+ less RNG than similar games.+ good backlore.+ moddable and there are mods for it.-/+ can be difficult to turtle or forward base defending tactics, though with some classes and races its more viable.- a map can get tough when you have a bad start (e.g. you lose some starting units or are to slow with leveling them). - still some annoying RNG, but luckily not so much.- minor point: while campaings are decent, I feel that the story could have been more epic. Can't really put my finger on it though, since the backlore (especially with AoW 1 and 2) is pretty expansive.My score: 9. Pro's to the developers for having patched this game many times.
