content:
26, 2014
												I remember playing Age of Wonders 1 and 2 so long ago.  I can't recall how many hours I dumped into those games, especially the second one.  It was the reinvention of Master of Magic, and I loved it.  You get the great world map combined with many fantastic races and tactical combat on separate maps.  I could not have been happier.  It was the fantasy version of Civilization in many respects.When I saw AoW3, I got anxious.  Finally it released, and I got to play it.  It truly has everything to remind me of the previous versions I loved, and then some.  Random Maps, finally.  Relevant units, yay.AoW3 has random maps.  This seems normal, but previously they did not.  So after a while, it becomes mundane with the same strategies and outcomes per scenario.  You can build cities!  Couldn't do that in the old days.  It was all preset and you took what was already there.  Units are relevant now.  In AoW2 the best strategy was to raze every single building and town you took (except your starting city), then destroy the neutral armies that appeared, and farm all the xp and items you could for your starting hero. He becomes nigh invincible, even to tier 3 units, and has absurd movement with flight, so he can just zoom around the map with a scorched earth strategy.  I have not tried to do this in AoW3, but I suspect it would be ineffective.If you liked the previous games in the series, you will still like this one. I cannot say anything bad about it. It is in line with everything I expected it to have. It stays true to the series, and offers some new things. The only thing it doesn't have, is the number of races that the priors had.  No Dark Elves, no Undead, etc... DLC right?  Seems fine.All that being said, I would go 8/10 if you like the genre or the old games.  Personally, it's a 7 for me, and that is just because although I want to enjoy the battles and fight them manually, they become something of a chore to me and I end up auto'ing most of them, even if its a huge super important fight.  I would not have the patience anymore for multiplayer if people do manual fights, yet the prospect of not having the option to manual fight seems to gut a large aspect of the game's draw for me.So I recommend this game overall, but you mind get a little bored with it if you have leaned towards RTS style games since playing AoW2, and maybe that's not worth the cost of the game for you.  Even so, it's a fine product and I am happy to support it, even if I don't play it as much as I thought I would.  (so many good games these days)

												This game is a puzzle. Not a puzzler game - it is a jigsaw of likes and disklikes. It has medicore graphics (both models and effects), sound gets a bit annoying at times and the creator of the UI could learn a lot from authors of those implemented f.e. in Might and Magic Heroes VI. BUT!The research is quite fun. The magic is awesome (and I mean owesome in an old style way; if you played Master of Magic, you'd know what i maen) and the resource system is simple and neat. Also you have bazzilion of skills for your heroes (because when they lvl up, you can experience a point based skill buying system - and it's good IMO) and the number of units in game is sick.The way the map is composed is known from titles such as Civ and other 4X fantasy themed games, BUT it also contains ruins, vaults, ancient burial ground, dragon lairs, mana sources, all sort of "pick me up" goodies and more.Conclusion: at first I hesitated even considering the game worth playing. But now, after some hours into it I'm happy I have it. If there would be a scale to judge the quality of a game, I would give it a strong 78 out of 100. AND if the devs get to work and create some patches fixing the UI and animation glitches - it will be much more.

content:
ry 16, 2016
												Where do I start...let me first say this game has definitely bkown away my expectations and what a turn based game should be. I have been a follower of the Heroes of Might and Magic series since the beginning. Developers at the Heroes camp need to take a page out of this book and use it. The biggest thing I like about this game is the option to ally with either a human or AI opponent and then play on whatever map you like. There are no restrictions to this at all. Just like in Civ games where all the options are open and you create the game for how you want to play. Same thing here. Being able to go around the map with your hero and its accompanied army just seeking out riches and enemy armies is so cool. Also your allies can travel with you and go into battle with you. First time I have ever seen that implemented into a game before. Juat imagine taking on a enemy faction along with your buddy online or hotseat taking on whatever came your way. Casting spells and supporting each other. This game does it right. I recommend to anyone this series of games. Plus two huge dlc addons available as well. Can't wait to take anothwr turn!

content:
er 1, 2016
												Gameplay has me totally hooked.Graphics are pretty. The animations are really beautifully done and I love how each race/hero combination feels totally different. Sound is good. Music is a bit shallow but theres mods to add more music in.Character development is good. Civilization building is deep enough but this is a combat game mainly. That said there are many ways to win and you can adjust the winning conditions to your liking such as allied victory etc, it doesn't have to be to the death.The story mode seems like a lot of fun and theres many hours of content there. I enjoyed what I played of it, though I quickly went on to the random map generator which is absolutely fantastic! You can customise so many things in the game and the character creator is wonderful to play with.Theres plenty of mods to play about with on the workshop to improve things further.Basically all there is to say. Awesome sauce game <3 Highly recommend it.(I bought the xpacs too, so I can't speak for vanilla alone)

content:
ber 29, 2014
												Updated: Eternal LordsNow, after the second expansion, Age of Wonders surpassed Crusaders Kings as the game I had played the most, so I could say it is now a great game.I would say it plays like Magic the gathering, if you throw away all that silliness about cards and instead you are a Powerful Ruler, with scores of fantasy armies to command and fanatasy enemies to conquer!-----At first I didn't like nor disliked this game; I thought it had some neat ideas but that didn't quite worked. I didn't ever try the campaigns: I bought this game for the random maps, to have an experience closer of a 4x game in a fantasy scenario.And it was so boring. I would literally fall asleep playing the game.Maybe I didn't "get" it at first, now that I bought The Golden Realms expansion and tried it again. The game looks a lot more solid. It is fun to play, the A.I. is competent in defending the new gameplay mechanics of Seals. With the expansion it isn't a great game yet , but is a very competent one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2015
												Fantastic game.  A wonderful game for fantasy turn-based strategy gamers.  A rich fantasy world on the strategy map, plus a rich turn-based tactical combat.  It has a feeling of high quality throughout.  As I write this it is version 1.704 with two expansions, so there has been a lot of polishing.  There is sufficient richness to keep it totally aborbing at both the strategic map and tactical map levels.  I always get the "I want to take one more turn" feeling from this game.  It's like living in a rich fantasy world of the imagination.  I like this type of game more than the strategic map only games such as Fallen Enchantress, Sorcerer King, or Endless Legend.  I respect those games, but I find I spend my time playing this one.  A nice tutorial campaign and a searchable tome of knowledge make this game accessible to new  players such as myself.  A tip of the hat to the developer, Triumph Studios.  I'm won over as a fan of this game.

content:
ber 19, 2014
												With the strategic and tactical mix, AoW3 has that Master of Magic feel while retaining the familiarity of the AoW 1 and 2 games.  I have enjoyed this game very much.  The classes seem to be very similar and playing them doesn't really require a different strategy for each.  Fewer balanced classes that played differently would have been more enjoyable but very few games have ever gotten that formula right.  I also find that occasionally I can win a difficult battle with autocombat ex:  (two six man armies each led by a hero against four fliers and a hunter in a city) that I couldn't win manually and vice versa ex: (I beat an eight man army lead by a hero with three elven archers).  Not sure what that's about but if I redo a battle a bunch of times and get my butt kicked I can occasionally win it with autocombat.  Also a little frustrating when my hero doesn't get disjunction to research during a random game but oh well makes for a challenge.

content:
5, 2014
												The game has great promise and is initially fun to play.  The campaigns are kind of fun.  There is no real story behind the campaigns, from what I've seen so far.  The graphics are very good.  However, after several games played through to the end, you will find that they all wind up coming down to the same thing, a bunch of the same types of units slugging it out.The game only has about 2 dozen playable units, but they changed the names slightly (depending on race) and changed the appearance.  Example Dwarf Manticore Rider, Draconian Manticore Rider, Elven Manticore Rider.  They all have almost the same stats, but look different.  The racial differences are too insignificant to make a difference.  The spells and traits, although there are many types, are for the most part not enough to make up for the overwhelming power of Tier IV and above units.  You can use different battle tactics, such as flanking, and get a bonus on your attack.  Currently, wounded units fight at full strength.  Heroes are limited in how many can be acquired in the game, but you can have as many other units as you can afford.The balance is horrible overall.Instead of creating a complex version of Rock, Paper, Scissors, they made it so it is just a bunch of Rocks fighting it out.  The rocks all look different!  But they are still Rocks.Every high quality strategic and tactical game out there is designed in such a way that the units/skills/abilities/spells are either complimentary to one another, or a counter to one another.  These high quality games have tremendous depth because there are so many options in how the game is played.  They understand that there should be strengths and weaknesses to almost all choices.  If, for example, I rushed in with a bunch of tanks I would get chewed up by the anti-tank helocoptors, which are themselves weak to anti-air units, etc.  AOW III does not really do this.  Instead it is a slug fest between the hardest hitting, high hitpoint units.  Basically, it's just a bunch of tanks fighting it out.  Booorrring.I really want to like this game...*Update* I'm still playing it, bugs and all.  Until they balance the game better and offer more depth, I will continue to give it a thumbs down.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												This game is a wonderful continuation for a long-time fan of Age of Wonders.  It polishes up what was lacking in the previous games while also bringing in welcome changes such as removing forced alignment from players and new spells.However, one of the most glaring issues with this game is that it suffers from you not buying the entire game.  While this isn't a severe problem for this game specifically compared to other games, it will not be as complete as older games.  There are not as much races (you can complete the race splash by buying DLC), not as much content, not as much pre-made scenarios, etc. than the previous games.  It feels like the game was intentionally cut up to serve the players the rest of the content with DLC.If you can live with the DLC, this is a fantastic game to buy.

content:
ber 25, 2014
												Did you or do you love the Heroes Might and Magic games?!Did you or do you love the Disciples games?! (I have heard bade things about Ressurection so ignore that one!)Then you will LOVE this game! Do not fret so much on the people talking so negatively about this game.If you love long hours for one game (I have been playing the second campain mission for days now. Yea its that intense)building or taking over cities to widen your territory for more resources, and intense turn-based battles (or auto-battle), get this game! It has the large maps of Heroes, with the army formations of Disciples--- (6 whatevers per army including heroes and its not quantity like the 'zongz' or 'hordes' in Heroes, only one each unit (althought there can be 1,3, or 6 "people" in one unit formation)and instead of changing like they do in Disciples, they "level up" and get stronger.)--- while adding its own spin. You can make builders and settlers that make roads, cities, forts, and watchtowers. Its own spells and such.Like Heroes you have all kinds of spells you can research and use (although you do not have to build a mage guild). Unlike Heroes you do not "go into" a city, a panel just pops up and you select it. Although the city look does change over time. Sort of like a TW 2 Rome, where little houses spread out around it. So who really wants to read every little detail. You can go watch Youtube vidoes of actaul gameplay right? Games like these arnt for gamers who want a Ryse Rome kind of game. A salute my fellow, slowly take over every inch of the map and clear it out, plus build it all up how you want, gamers! Go Warcraft 1-3 and BFME games XDI will say, at first I regretted buying this. OMG why did I buy this when I can just play my Disciples II and have basically the same thing. HA! Discpiles is (while I have not played the new one from this year (2014..drool....) no where near as intense and LONG (again think Heroes!) as AoW. Granted it is limited. Each race has the exact same building, and each unit while looks, attributes and powers are different, each tier or class (Tier 1 Calvary or Tier 3 Archer) is comparribly the same. If you want a good, intense, in depth fighting game that you can or want to spend huge amount of time ------- (I have put in 17.5 hours as I post this, maybe 2 of which was on the first mission, the rest on the second campain mission AND I am only half way through the map....well the top level anyhow ;) I have barely done anything on the under level. OH I FORGOT! With builders or special units like the giant beetle you can 'dig; through certain walls and explore more, while more or less combining the whole under level....be careful you arnt the only one who can :P)-------- get this game!Even do like me and put it on your wishlist and wait for a sale.Hope this helped. Feel free to ask any questions to me!If you do not know what Heroes is OR Discplis. Go explore and enjoy:) Trust me. You will love it.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												This title reminds me of the Heros of Might and Magic series and has many similarities to it.  Fans of it will likely enjoy Age of Wonders as well.  It improves on the familiar formula with ideas from other strategy games such as cities which expand over time and generate income from resources withing their spheres of infulence.  Unlike Heroes you are able to estlablish new cities on the map as well as fortifications and road networks.  Armies made up completely of flying units are able to cross lakes and mountains and terraforming spells can improve your territory or ruin your enemy's, effecting the morale of cities, which have terrian preferences and dislikes depending on their racial characteristics.  A unified research system unlocks new spells, units, traits, abilities, etc.  Like heroes the map has an overworld and underworld providing difficult stategic oppertunities for surprise attacks and shortcuts.  Unlike Heros, multiple armies in adjactent hexes can participate in the same battle for epic scale combat and seige warfare.  Multiple unique army leaders can band together into a fighting unit along with expendable military units in groupings of up to six, and will fight alongside their troops in battle as cavalry units capable of both ranged and melee attacks as well as spells and special abilities.  Leaders also gain experience and can be improved with increased stats and other perks upon leveling up.  Familiar fantasy races compete in this setting such as Elves, Orcs, Draconians, Dwarves, and Undead, amoung others.  Two campains are available with the game as well as custom maps and multiplayer options.

Its own spells and such.Like Heroes you have all kinds of spells you can research and use (although you do not have to build a mage guild). Unlike Heroes you do not "go into" a city, a panel just pops up and you select it. Although the city look does change over time. Sort of like a TW 2 Rome, where little houses spread out around it. So who really wants to read every little detail. You can go watch Youtube vidoes of actaul gameplay right? Games like these arnt for gamers who want a Ryse Rome kind of game. A salute my fellow, slowly take over every inch of the map and clear it out, plus build it all up how you want, gamers! Go Warcraft 1-3 and BFME games XDI will say, at first I regretted buying this. OMG why did I buy this when I can just play my Disciples II and have basically the same thing. HA! Discpiles is (while I have not played the new one from this year (2014..drool....) no where near as intense and LONG (again think Heroes!) as AoW. Granted it is limited. Each race has the exact same building, and each unit while looks, attributes and powers are different, each tier or class (Tier 1 Calvary or Tier 3 Archer) is comparribly the same. If you want a good, intense, in depth fighting game that you can or want to spend huge amount of time ------- (I have put in 17.5 hours as I post this, maybe 2 of which was on the first mission, the rest on the second campain mission AND I am only half way through the map....well the top level anyhow ;) I have barely done anything on the under level. OH I FORGOT! With builders or special units like the giant beetle you can 'dig; through certain walls and explore more, while more or less combining the whole under level....be careful you arnt the only one who can :P)-------- get this game!Even do like me and put it on your wishlist and wait for a sale.Hope this helped. Feel free to ask any questions to me!If you do not know what Heroes is OR Discplis. Go explore and enjoy:) Trust me. You will love it.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												I don't even know where to begin to describe the high amount of production quality and really how deep this game is. To start its fair to say this game is the offspring of Civilization 5 and XCOM: Enemy Unknown all set in a fantasy realm with magic and different races. You have large scale geographically diverse maps that allow you to build individual cities and armies to form a massive empire. Strategy and tactics have to be considered as all combat is done in standalone battlefields, not the overworld. The tile of the defender determines the actual battlefield; I was on attacked on a bridge, outnumbered 2:1 and I won the fight because I funneled the attackers onto this narrow bridge and let them have it. Age of Wonders 3 merges the best things about Civilization 5 and tactical games like XCOM to make a game that really reminds of you the choices you've made and the paths you lead. Pros:- Stunning graphics- In depth tactical battles- Intelligent AI- Varied multi-tier units and spells/abilities- Robust leader customization- Two campaigns; divided by difficulty and are very lengthy- Features Underground tunnels/caves to add an extra layer to the map- Alt+Tab friendly :)Cons- Steep learning curve, most advanced concepts aren't taught in the campaign until you've learned them the hard way- DRM online only, have to sign up for a third-party account to play- May take over your entire day if not carefulFinal Score = 90% / 100%

It seemed to me that the focus was too heavily on battles, and that the game was forcing every turn the player to do some actions dictated by the progress of the cities, rise of new heroes, etc. I felt a general lack of freedom. content:
14, 2016
												If you like games like the Civilization series, or the Heroes of Might & Magic series, and are hankering for a new high-fantasy strategy game to play, do yourself a favor and check this game out! This was my first experience with the Age of Wonders series, I was looking through the Steam store for something new, saw it and decided to give it a go. I didn't expect much given the usual quality of today's games but man was I surprised!Here is my pros and cons list based on my experience playing the base game, I haven't bought the expansion packs yet but I definitely plan to.Pros : - Challenging gameplay that requires you to think ahead, as well as think quickly on your feet.- Good AI.- Wide variety of fantasy creatures to go up against, or enlist in your own army.- Active modding community on the Steam Workshop.- Beautiful visuals.- Large arsenal of spells, abilities, upgrades and equipment that make each Leader feel unique.- Nice soundtrack that does a good job of adding to the immersion.- A character creation system that offers a good deal of customization for this sort of game.- Boatloads of replayability.Cons : - Some units and abilities seem rather imbalanced, but nothing gamebreaking.- Challenge can sometimes ramp up drastically.- Cities could use a bit more diversity, while it is possible to have a city that is specialized in performing a certain role, I haven't yet found that to be necessary and as a result all my cities have pretty much had the same buildings. I think this could have been improved by making a tech-tree for cities so you would have to decide what you want that city's main purpose to be. But, since the game is focused more on armies and combat rather than city building, this isn't a huge deal.- Very few visual changes on your Leaders and Heroes in regard to their equipment, the only items that change your appearance are your mount and your weapon. This is more of a personal desire and not so much something the game did wrong,  it IS a strategy game after all and would require alot of effort to implement. but still, I was a bit let down when I looted a very awesome looking helmet and chest piece only to find that it didn't affect my appearance. Once again, not a huge deal though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2016
												Age of Wonders III is an incredibly fun, turn-based strategy game that is formed around its "deep fantasy" theme. Rather than progressing through a series of eras, as other popular turn-based, world-domination strategy games do, this game puts the player in charge of one of many fantasy races and it is the player's job to push their people to victory.One mechanical element that draws me to this game, and one that is fairly unique to AoW3 (as far as I know), is the tactical hex-based combat. Unlike the Civilization series (which I also recommend), AoW3 allows players to take direct control over their armies when they are engaged in combat with enemy forces. Instead of forcing an odds-based animation and resolution of the battle (which is still an option, but not required), the game allows players to enter into a battlefield that is generated based on the terrain types of the embattled hex as well as its special features and those of the neighboring hexes. This provides tactically savvy players the opportunity to achieve satisfying victories in the face of almost guaranteed auto-resolve defeats.Another element of the game that I find quite satisfying is the ability to create your own hero character who serves as your civilization's leader for the duration of the game. There are a significant number of races, classes, and looks based on each of those that players can choose from, and there's even a rudimentary skill selection process for your leader that can help players who want to lead their race by pursuing a certain playstyle during their game. These leader units not only represent your race in diplomatic encounters with other players, but they also serve as actual, usable units on the battlefield that can lead players' forces to gallant victories (or crushing defeats).The base game has a lot to explore for new players, so definitely start with that if you're just trying the game out. Once you get the hang of it, and also develop an inevitable liking for the game, I would highly recommend the DLC that introduces new races and campaigns. This DLC adds to the already numerous choices for leaders, races, and playstyles, and should give players who like the campaigns many more hours of content to play through.

												Classic 4X gameplay, with a stronger focus on combat that diplomacy and a stronger focus on unit managment as opposed to city/kingdom managment. The tur-based strategic batles allow you to spectate and interact with the units in a way most other 4X games lack. The customization in Class and Race allow for hightened replayability and a greater sence of diversity amoung the units and opponents. I would highly reccomend this game for anyone who enjoys 4X and strategy games. Graphics are colorful and detailed as well, and the music/sound is good enough. 9/10

Fewer balanced classes that played differently would have been more enjoyable but very few games have ever gotten that formula right.  I also find that occasionally I can win a difficult battle with autocombat ex:  (two six man armies each led by a hero against four fliers and a hunter in a city) that I couldn't win manually and vice versa ex: (I beat an eight man army lead by a hero with three elven archers).  Not sure what that's about but if I redo a battle a bunch of times and get my butt kicked I can occasionally win it with autocombat.  Also a little frustrating when my hero doesn't get disjunction to research during a random game but oh well makes for a challenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												The game has great promise and is initially fun to play.  The campaigns are kind of fun.  There is no real story behind the campaigns, from what I've seen so far.  The graphics are very good.  However, after several games played through to the end, you will find that they all wind up coming down to the same thing, a bunch of the same types of units slugging it out.The game only has about 2 dozen playable units, but they changed the names slightly (depending on race) and changed the appearance.  Example Dwarf Manticore Rider, Draconian Manticore Rider, Elven Manticore Rider.  They all have almost the same stats, but look different.  The racial differences are too insignificant to make a difference.  The spells and traits, although there are many types, are for the most part not enough to make up for the overwhelming power of Tier IV and above units.  You can use different battle tactics, such as flanking, and get a bonus on your attack.  Currently, wounded units fight at full strength.  Heroes are limited in how many can be acquired in the game, but you can have as many other units as you can afford.The balance is horrible overall.Instead of creating a complex version of Rock, Paper, Scissors, they made it so it is just a bunch of Rocks fighting it out.  The rocks all look different!  But they are still Rocks.Every high quality strategic and tactical game out there is designed in such a way that the units/skills/abilities/spells are either complimentary to one another, or a counter to one another.  These high quality games have tremendous depth because there are so many options in how the game is played.  They understand that there should be strengths and weaknesses to almost all choices.  If, for example, I rushed in with a bunch of tanks I would get chewed up by the anti-tank helocoptors, which are themselves weak to anti-air units, etc.  AOW III does not really do this.  Instead it is a slug fest between the hardest hitting, high hitpoint units.  Basically, it's just a bunch of tanks fighting it out.  Booorrring.I really want to like this game...*Update* I'm still playing it, bugs and all.  Until they balance the game better and offer more depth, I will continue to give it a thumbs down.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 27, 2016
												Age of Wonders 3 is an excellent 4X strategy game that is hard to learn, but rewarding to play. Compared to other games of it's type, AW3 offers a much deeper combat system and a wide veriety of strategies and compositions. If you have a lot of spare time, love/are interested in grand strategy titles, and/or like the themes of traitional medieval fantacy, I would highly reccomend this game.Pros:- Excellent turn based combat system that favors strategy over raw stats- Races and Classes feel unique to play and favor sometimes wildly different strategies. Lots of options.- Optional, yet deep, character customization.- The world is fun to explore - and very rewarding. There's always something productive to do.- DLC adds game changing elements that are worth investing in if you enjoy the base game- You CAN add more races into your empire, leading to even more wild compositions- Campaign mode offers a more flavorful world, and each unit has a flavorful story tied to it. World is more immersive.Cons:- Some race/class combinations are much weaker than others.- Tutorial is very bad - game is hard to learn, and harder to understand.- Campaign maps favor rush tatics over late game strategies. Also, unfathomable gaps exist between difficult levels (easy being almost braindead, and normal being infuriatingly hard.)- Barebones diplomacy system. - The base game its all about domination. Mre options are availible with DLC, but I would advise rushing to buy something if you don't know whether or not its right for you.- Cities lack much thematic diversity, are like the diplomatic system are more barebone.- No "just one more turn" button.I give Age of Wonders 3 a 9/10. Its pros outweigh almost all of its cons, and with a more in depth diplomacy system and optional post victory gameplay, it could easily have earned a 10/10 from me.

												Age of Wonders III is in many ways the true successor to Master of Magic. The overworld and spell research sections are very good, with plenty of options for replayability and difficult choices. But where the game really shines is in the tactical battles. The wide variety of units and abilities ensures that there is always a new factor to force you to change your pattern. The is also a multiplayer scene, if after you've finished the (extensive!) single-player campaigns and want to face some real challenges!Last, the sound design and art are top-notch. Those sorts of things are easy to overlook, but they can really make a difference!

content:
er 2, 2016
												I enjoy AoW3 quite a bit, but the more I played it the more stale the AI got for me.  It's not that it's bad per se, just that it's predictable and usually very passive.  Usually they will turtle up in their cities if you are roaming nearby, even if they are a fair bit stronger than you.  This forces a lot of siege warfare, something that I don't think the game does very well.  You can't sit outside their gates and siege them down, you have to fight their forces full strength every time at their walls.  It gets tedious.  There are ways around this (happiness penalties/strategic spells mainly from Rogue) but the AI gets pretty significant boosts to its economy and happiness which makes it kind of moot.  That said, I still think the game is great.  The units are diverse, the asymmetrical balancing is rather good, and a lot of the racial specializations are nice to have.  Things that I'd like to see in the next iteration:- Smarter, less cheesy AI- Proper siege mechanics- More emphasis on skirmishes/raiding- More cultural/racial buildings and the addition of monuments/wonders- Option for fast move in combat with online play

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Age of wonders 3 is a turnbased strategygame, with some basebuilding but with a heavy focus on exploration and combat. The look, feel and even some gamemechanics of the game draws heavily upon game like Civilization, Warlock and Heroes of might and magic, wich makes for a easy start into the game, if you are just a bit familiar with these titles. The game offers huge maps to explore, with a lot of sidequest, powerups and "dungeons". The terran does impact things like movement and combatwill of your units/armies, as well as the output of certain cities upgrades and even the area in wich combat takes place. The game offers very different ways of upgrading the skills of your heroes, as well as your spells (combat and world) and it really feels like every decision have an impact on the gameplay.Flaws and bugs are few in numbers and rarely more than an slight irritation and never a deal breaker. Definately worth your time and money, if you're into strategy, rpg and empirebuilding.

content:
4
												It's a good game. I think it's more fun than Civ 5, but I agree with some of the reviewers that some of the game mechanics don't make sense. A squad with 1 hp still doing full damage and the flanking rules don't work really well. It's better in many ways than AOW: Shadow Magic with the more 4x elements. But there are some problems... The tools for managing lots of cities and armies are lacking. There's a global spell that the enemy can cast that lower all your armies moral so you can't win any battles and everyone leaves you by the time you can cast a disenchant strong enough for it, so that's pretty unbalanced. It's difficult to get used to right-clicking all the time after playing modern games, so it'd be nice to have an option to have that work differently.

content:
5, 2014
												As fan of the Series since AoW1 the reader of this positive review might think, that I'd just be a good fanboy to a well made series. However after being frustreted with 2 other spinoff of Roundbased Game Series, AoW3 was a very positive surprise for me!Other than in those mentioned other "improved" game experiences, the developers took to heart the initial strengths of the game, and preserved them, while adding new concepts like the neutral cities and the commander classes.And so you can be pretty sure what to get: a solid Age of Wonders experience with various cool new Ideas built in.There are a few minor things I'm not too happy about.For once the actual number of neutral cities is rather low (4, I believe). When I first met those new type of cities, I imagined them being a core concept of the game, with having 8, or even a dozen of them, seeing as the count of playable races shrinked to 6 . I thought the big diversity of units we know from the predecessors just wandered off into neutrality.So I was kind of depressed to see that you mainly got those 4 neutral cities, and the positive "first contact"-experience was just something for the first few maps.Later on however, I realized why the race count went down like that:The race you play is entwined with the class you choose, giving you certain racial units with custom skins, which do have some of the racial benefits, but are actually a boon from your class.This makes the effort to create an ingame race exponentialy as high as in the predecessors, and because of that, I can very well understand the seemingly low number of races.On the positive side however, it adds diversity to the game, since the playstyle is not only about racial pick and magical spheres anymore, but adds a third layer of personalisation through the classes.There are some other minor setbacks from the original series in my point of view: The number of buildings on the map to recruit neutral units has been reduced to 1 (tavern); There are randomized heroes with basic class startups to get, instead of the heroes from AoW2, which kind of grow on to you because of their funny descriptions, and their prepicked own advantages; And also the later stages of the campaign become incredibly hero-dependant due to the leveling commander-heroes and the neutral heroes you transfer from map to map.But enough nitpicking.If you enjoyed the predecessors or are generaly into well-balanced tactical round-based game experiences.. make sure to get this one! The classes and races are very well designed, and the campaigns are bit straightforward storywise, but still diversified and interesting. The few experiences I made with online gaming so far were positive as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												So, I played the original Age of Wonders and Age of Wonders 2, as well Shadow Magic, which was a stand alone expansion for Age of Wonders 2, so I was naturally quite interested when I heard Age of Wonders 3 was coming out. Somehow I'd managed to miss that it was even in production until about a month before it was released. Nevertheless, after starting to read about the game, I was a bit wary as some of the changes did not seem positive. However, being a fan of the series as a whole, I had to at least give it a try.So... is Age of Wonders 3 a good game? Well, your answer to that would no doubt be influenced by whether you have played any of the previous games in the series. Having played them, I would say, yes this is a good game but, relative to its time, the game is perhaps not as good as the previous titles in the series. For those of you who don't know, Age of Wonder is a fantasy turn-based strategy, with large amounts of magic, heroes and different races. In Age of Wonders, your leader was a hero and he or she travelled about with your army, gaining levels, exploring ancient ruins and so on. For Age of Wonders 2, your hero became a wizard who spent all his or her time sitting in their tower casting spells. With Age of Wonders 3, the system has gone back to that of the original Age of Wonders (i.e. your leader being an active participant in the world) so in this sense it has been an improvement from 2.Also the graphics are quite good and has a certain fantastical feel about it, I don't know if it's the shades and the hues, but it does feel quite vivid and rich. Also when you zoom out in the world screen, the view changes to a stylised map, as drawn on parchment, think the map of Middle-Earth, which I think looks really good.One of the biggest issues I had with the game prior to getting it was the massive cut the number of races, now there are only six: Goblins, Orcs, Dwarfs, Humans, Draconians and High Elves. This basicaly means many of the races from AoW2 are gone: Dark Elves/Wood Elves (although there is an in-game reason why they no longer exist, basically they kissed and made up and reformed as the High Elves), Frostlings, Halflings, etc. And yes, I would say the lack of races is quite noticable. I've played just 2 levels in one of the campaigns and during that time I've captured and held cities belonging to every single race in the game except for the dwarves. Considering I've only just started the third level, it seems odd that I've nearly played as every single race already. So, yes, I suppose there is certainly much less variation than there was.One of the ways that is suposed to reduce the imact of this lack of variation is by having small settlements belonging to 'minor races' which you can capture and then train units from other races. For example, I captured a fey settlement and was thus able to train various fey units, and construct buildings to improve them, as well as unlock different units that could be trained. I was actually quite surprised how much depth there was in this. You seem to be able to train 5-6 different units, and a fair number of buildings. I was expecting 2-3 different units at most. Nevertheless, they're still less in depth than a city from one of the main six races, and of course you can't build them.Combat is pretty much the same as the previous Age of Wonders games, and the additions with the new 3D engine are nice, for example having units consist of multiple men, the numbers of which go down as the unit gets injured. The system regarding magic spheres is a bit different to the previous titles in the series. Essentially, each hero has three different specialisations and if you're creating your own hero you can pick three from a list. These consist of 6 different areas of magic (water, fire, air, earth, creation and destruction), expander and explorer. Because of this, you can select a minimum of one area of magic and a maximum of three. This influences what you can research and what can subsequently use. When you do create a hero, you get quite a lot of customisation options in terms of apperance. You also have a range of different classes you can select for your hero: dreadnaught, druid, sorcerer, etc. Each of these gives you at least one unique building (which may be upgradable) and unique unit, however apart from that there seems to be little differences between the different classes. Being one class or the other doesn't influence the specialisations you can select for example, and these specialisations seem to have a much greater influence over your character than what class they are.The music in Age of Wonders 3 isn't anything special in my opinion. It's alright, but it's not amazingly noticable and there haven't been any songs I've particularly sat up and particularly enjoyed, compared to Age of Wonders 1 where there were a few songs I particularly liked, such as the March of the Halflings.People have reported having FPS issues, and I get them myself, but for me personally it's mostly fine, just a bit slow but certainly playable. The developers are aware of this and are currently working on fixing it.Also, I have to comend the voice acting in Age of Wonders 3. I've only played one campaign but the voice acting for the main character from whose point of view the stoy is told is actually very good. I admit this review hasn't been the most well structured, but to conclude, I think Age of Wonders 3 is a good game, perhaps a very good game but not an excellent game, and not as good as the previous games in the series and it does have some flaws. It is certainly is screaming out for some kind of expansion/DLC just to add a bit more variation and depth. Even with the minor races you can find and recruit, six major races does seem a bit few but I certainly don't regret buying it.

												This game is excellent. It has good graphics, good gameplay. It was the game I was looking for after being disappointed by Fallen Enchantress : Legendary Heroes.  The tactical combat in this game is much better with varying terrain and destroyable obstacles.  If you are a fan of Master of Magic, then you will probably like this.  I have just started the game so I have not seen all the features/limitations but overall it is a really good game and is actually worth full price, altho it is a bit expensive at 43$, but it is still worth it. The game is also integrated with Steam Workshop so user made maps are easily obtainable.edit: I also have come to find out that this game is gets regular updates that even bring in some new game mechanics and it also has to original expansion packs, not just dlc.  The same thing about updates and expansions can definatly not be said for Fallen Enchantress : Legendary Heroes.Edit: Despite looking much better than Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes, this game is better optimized and coded and doesn't suffer from any stuttering whatsoeverI can't stress how much better this game is over FE: LH.  These people did a much better job than those people.This game is always challenging and keeps getting better and more enjoyable for me as I become a better player. Also the user interface is great.

content:
r 4, 2015
												TLDR: 7.5/10It's very good but there are so many things that drive me mad that I can't honestly say it's a classicAge of Wonders is basically what Heroes of Might & Magic should have become after the countless crapfest sequels that didn't try anything new. The game has a wonderful tactical combat system that puts most regular tactical combat games to shame, it's really exciting and there are so many cool abilities and spells to use. Overall there's a lot of content (I'm just reviewing the vanilla game) and plenty of variety for a good 1-2 playthroughs of each Class.The downsides? Well like most 4X style games, it doesn't handle scale well. The economy is super simple and isn't the focus of the game (unlike Civ V for example), so it falls into the trap of "I don't ♥♥♥♥ing care about these 6 cities I've built". I know I should care, and I need to care in the late game... it's just too much tedious management with very little impact on your game as a whole, especially compared to the early game. Likewise for armies. You start with 1x 6-unit army, including your hero, and have nice little skirmishes. Then you get Hero after Hero with army after army and before you know it you've got 10 armies you have to manage and fight with. It's just too much and I find the turns take so long and the decisions become so diluted down that I quit most games once I've killed my main rival. It's a pain to finish an Age of Wonders game.Minor gripes;  Bone Dragon independent parties flying around from outside the fog of war and destroying your entire army isn't fun. It spams you with 'This hero wants to join' every ♥♥♥♥ing turn, which is soooo god damn time consuming over the course of a 100-200 turn game. Furthermore, the extra heroes you get are very sub-standard and some, like the Dreadnaught, are basically useless as you lack the Class buildings for your cities to get any of the units that Hero would need. Auto-Combat is sometimes a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, killing dudes that obviously wouldn't have died if you'd done manual combat... then again, the combat does take so long that you find yourself using Auto for most situations that aren't an 18vs18 city siege.Tiny gripes which might be my fault for sucking? I find the whole economy and tech side of the game a little shallow. It seems that for most classes it's all about just getting as many Shadow Stalkers or Eldrich Horrors as you possibly can, removing any unit diversity and relegating most units to the 'useless leagues'. The game does do a good job of keeping diversity high into the mid-game, but end-game it's just dull. Also that Call of the Wild spell that summons 3 beasts every ♥♥♥♥ing round is so stupidly good, ♥♥♥♥ dat ♥♥♥♥!

content:
15, 2015
												So far a very good turn-based strategy game and easy for someone who's more than a bit rusty at the genre to get into without much frustration. Some pros and cons so far:Pros: Easy to learn, tutorial pages are fairly informative and not intrusive if you hate having to go through tutorials that either are too long or too detailed...or the reverse. Fantasy setting is fairly straight forward (elves vs. orcs in basic campaign with human scum everywhere) but engaging storytelling and voice acting works wellTurn-based design is very comfortable if you've played this type of game in the pastCons:More than possible to wall yourself in a corner by accident (sort of comes with the turf though)Autosave will occasionally save right before a move you really wish you hadn't taken (so save often)YMV on this but I have found on occasion that I think I'm clicking to attack one troop and get another by accident. Not sure its a game issue or operator error (probably the latter)Anyway so far a 9/10 for me would get 1 more point if the fantasy elements were more exotic and interesting but otherwise quite easy and enjoyable to get into while being challenging to overcome. Will update if further play changes any details in this review (I'm only about 6 hours in to the initial campaign).

Olemme kavereiden kanssa pelanneet jo neljä tuntia, mutta emme ole päässeet alkua pitemmälle.
